Comment: It already has gone wrong many times, but yeah, we are also going to get more and more of the stuff like the Weezer police shooting thing.   Constitutional law still is higher than Trump law, and Trump is giving temporary permits for mercenaries to be above Constitutional law. When any case ends up in court it's two opposing laws which at the moment still leans to the Constitution.   If you have one guy who is innocent under Constitutional law but guilty under Trump vs. another guy who has the vice versa laws, who is the winner and loser in this?   Also, when secret police who are permitted to hide their identity ever way possible when their job is to disappear and murder people, what is stopping citizens from pretending to be secret police?   As the law stands most everybody has the right to bear arms and also has the right to self defense. That right to self defense means that there's a lot of situations where they are allowed to kill somebody if they believe their life is in danger under the general definition. If a secret police attempts to kidnap you doesn't that give the right to self defense to the person being kidnapped and even the people attempting to protect that person. Prior to Trump's orders that type of thing was my guess is over 95% have the right to self defense taking each account on a case by case basis meaning that some of the variables and legal definitions or even legal mistakes could change that.   Trump's orders enter worse than Wild West legal territory. By some standard plenty of the Wild West sort of had self defense figured out.
